marginalia.translation: Crespin, in some treatises that are absolutely indispensable for a legal professional, published a series of compendia and an arrangement of all the titles, which are explained in the order of the 'Digest', and a collection of the writings of van Wesenbeek and Cujas.

position.marginalia_text: A quo ordiendum, tanqu[am] à Synopse Pandectaru[m]; multa paucis complectente: Et certè Hopperi Paratitla sunt etiam valdèpra[e]gnantia: nec quicqu[am] in hoc genere pressius, aut fertilius. Mihi maximè placent, Freigij Ratio generalis Logica: Hopperi Ratio specialis Juridica: Speculatoris Ratio specialissima Pragmatica: cum Bartholi Distinctionibus, ad Acumen Ingenij aduocatoij; et Vigelij Repertorio, ad Certitudinem Judicij decisorij: nec extat hodiè quicqu[am] tam singulare in suo genere.

marginalia.translation: It is worth beginning with him, just as it is with a synopsis of the 'Digest', to absorb many things with little effort. Certainly, Hoppers's 'Paratitla' is also extremely pregnant; there is nothing more compressed or more fruitful of its kind. My favourites are Freigius on general logical reasoning, Hoppers on specific legal reasoning, Durand on the most specific pragmatic reasoning, with Bartolus's 'Distinctiones' for the sharpness of the advocate's intelligence and Vigel's 'Repertorium' for the decisiveness of the presiding judge. There currently exists nothing so particular of its kind.
